text: hey guys it's elise from my cupcake
addiction today i'm sharing with you a
very special cake that I made for my son
all of his third birthday
he loves diggers loves dump trucks so we
decided to go with a construction themed
party and I decided speaking this really
cool really simple digger cake on the
outside when you cut into it it's full
construction print on the inside so it's
kind of one of those surprise inside
cakes let's get started to make this
cake you're going to need some either

got some plastic wrap and quite a large
14-inch cake board I'm using some gel
color pastes in an egg yellow and a
black I've got a spoon a bread knife a
sharp knife and offset spatula I've got
a cake tin so I'm using an 8-inch cake
tin as well as a six inch and a four
inch cake board but you can also just
cut two circles from parchment paper for
my dirt and rubble I'm using some
crushed up Oreos and I've got to be

chopped co2 popcorn some chopped coated
honeycomb I've got some Maltesers or
whoppers and I'd also found some

choice today is chocolate ganache so I
will link to that recipe in the

the first thing you want to do is take
your vanilla mix and you want to mix
that up
as per your recipe instructions once
it's all mixed up you want to take your

of that greaseproof or baking paper for
the top taking a long piece of wax paper
I fold it into three what this does is
it helps to line the tin but it also
helps to give you like an extended
height on your cake tin so you can
actually bake your cakes a little bit
higher than the general three or so
inches you can bake
up to a four inch high cake a wrap that
throws folded collar around my hand and
stick it straight into the Katyn you
don't need to grease this you can just
line it with that baking paper and it's

generous amount of that I'm just going
to mix that coloring through my vanilla

just tip it all into that 8-inch cake
tin and we're going to pop it off into

bake I flatten it down and then I'm
going to take that extra circle of
greaseproof paper and I'm going to sit
it on top this is going to help it to
rise a little bit more evenly and it's
also gonna stop it from cracking on top
as much pop that one off into a moderate
oven cook it as per your recipe
instructions then we'll come back and
we'll repeat the process with our
chocolate so once again you want to make
up your chocolate cake mix and we're
starting with the chocolate because it's
already a dark color here and then I'm
going to add some of that black food
color paste if you were to try and color
a vanilla cake mix here you'd need a ton

never get it quite this dark so starting
with a chocolate means already starting
with a darker colored cake then you're
adding a bit of black and we're going to
get that nice rich black color once
again lining your cake tin and in goes
that black mix smooth it down on top pop
in that extra circle of greaseproof or
baking paper and into the oven you want
to let both of those cakes completely
cook and completely cool before we start
doing anything else with them once
they're completely cooled you want to
take your serrated knife or your bread
knife and just cut the two tops off them
so that they have the same height and so
that you've just cut off any of those
kind of crispy edges you want to make
sure that these are both the same height
so cut them next to each other and then
you want to double wrap it in plastic
wrap and we're going to put those into
the freezer you don't want those to be
completely frozen solid about three to
five hours is perfect otherwise you can
make them a few days in advance freeze
them solid and bring them out about an
hour or so before you want to work with
them just so they start Thor a little
bit so now we're going to make some
black ganache by adding some of that
black food color paste to about half of
your batch of chocolate ganache this is
easiest to do when you can - is quite
warm and quite fluid now here's where
this cake gets technical so you'll see
I've got my two cake boards the first
cut we're going to make is going to be
on about a 45 degree angle and you want
to come
right around the edge of the cake this
is why it's imperative that your cake is
nice and firm but you can see that I'm
not having too much trouble getting my
knife in so it's not rock solid if it's
not firmer if it's really fresh and
still warm
fat cakes just going to crumble once
you've leave your first cut all the way
around you want to put your 6-inch cake
board and you're going to do the exact
same angle going all the way around so
you are coming in on that 45 degree
angle then you want to take your 4 inch
cake board and the same thing again this
is what makes the diagonal stripes if
you're not a hundred percent confident
with this technique or if you're pressed
for time you could always just slice

so you've got four layers and just stack
them on top of each other in alternating

zone looks exactly that the construction

sites this centerpiece here because I
haven't gone quite through the bottom
I'm just going to cut through so that
all of our pieces look roughly the same
and you want to leave your outer two
pieces still joined together because
they're going to be your flimsiest ones
to move repeat that process with your
black cake and you can see here how
delicate this center section is so be

stack these two together so you should
have eight pieces in your two different
colors this black one here did start to

happens to you don't worry about it
you'll see here I'm just pushing all of
the pieces of cake up and then I'm using

off to fill in any of those gaps once
these are all stacked in together we're
going to kind of glue them together with
that ganache so don't worry if they're a
little crumbly or they're not quite

filling in some of those little top
sections and what you should have is a
black cake with yellow than black then
yellow and a yellow cake with black then
yellow then black kind of alternating
with those two cakes once all of your
pieces are in you want to press them
down quite firmly with the palm of your
hand and then take some of that really
nice fluid chocolate ganache you'll see
how liquidy mine is if yours has started
to set or to firm up you can just pop it
in the microwave for 20 seconds or so so
it's really nice and fluid and I'm
scooping it on top and then I'm using my
knife just to scrape it around so
essentially I'm closing those two cakes
completely in that black ganache which
is going to seal all of those layers
together it's going to hold everything
together beautifully and it's going to
give us a really nice base to work with
once they're sealed just use a scraper
or a nice big piece of cardboard just to
pick up your cakes and you want to wrap
them again in plastic wrap and pop them
back off into the freezer for about half
an hour or so this is going to allow
that chocolate ganache to really set and
it's also going to allow those cakes to
fuse together now that we've chopped
them up and sort of stuck them all back
together like a jigsaw puzzle when they
come out of the freezer when you tip
them upside down you'll see that they've
still got kind of some gaps in the
bottom because we've stuffed them all
back together so a little bit more of
that ganache particularly in that bottom
center section and spread it over with
your offset spatula once again just to
stick everything together
now I'm putting this on quite a large

everything around it and I'm going to

can use the rest of the board to make
this cake look like it's a lot bigger

at the bottom of the cake essentially as
a glue just to stick it straight to the
board and then I'm going to put a little

layer just to stick the second layer to
the top so a bit of ganache don't take
it all the way out to the sides and then
flip your cake and on it goes there's
your two layers stacked and ready to go
because your cakes have been setting in
the freezer they should be quite cold
but just allow them five minutes or so
for that ganache to set in between the
two layers and that's going to stop the
two layers from sliding around when we
go to put on this next load of frosting
now this is the other half of my ganache
the half that I didn't color black and
you can see the difference in
consistency so I've made this and it's

you'll see here it's actually quite nice

don't be too fussy here this is a rubble
cake it's a construction cake it is

much you want to take your Oreo crumbs

to
pat around the edges to keep the shape
